prompt_text:
GRANT EXECUTIVE SUMMARY GENERATOR

Purpose: Create a compelling one-page executive summary to accompany your full grant proposal.

STEP 1: QUICK START CHECKLIST
Fill in these core details first.

Basic Information:
- Organization: [ORGANIZATION NAME]
- Funder: [FUNDER NAME]
- Request amount: [$AMOUNT]
- Grant purpose: [PURPOSE – e.g., “general operating support” or “youth employment program”]
- Grant period: [TIMEFRAME – e.g., “12 months” or “July 2025–June 2026”]
- Total project/program budget: [$TOTAL BUDGET]

Program Details:
- Program name: [PROGRAM NAME]
- Number served: [NUM PARTICIPANTS]
- Geography: [GEOGRAPHY – city/county/region]
- Population: [POPULATION – be specific]
- Delivery model: [DELIVERY MODEL – e.g., “weekly workshops,” “1:1 case management,” “mobile clinics”]
- Key sites/partners: [SITES/PARTNERS]

Funding Context:
- Confirmed or matching funds: [MATCH/LEVERAGE]
- Estimated per-participant cost (if relevant): [$COST PER PARTICIPANT]

Tone: [Select ONE: FORMAL / WARM / CASUAL]
- FORMAL: Precise, reserved language for institutional funders (foundations, government)
- WARM: Approachable, community-centered for family/local funders
- CASUAL: Plainspoken for relationship-based grassroots funders you know well

STEP 2: DETAILED INFORMATION (INFORMATION YOU’LL NEED)

Need Statement:
- Geography: [GEOGRAPHY]
- Population most affected: [POPULATION]
- Key data points (2–3 stats showing scale/urgency): [KEY DATA POINTS]
- Specific impact/harms: [IMPACT DESCRIPTION]

Solution:
- Program name: [PROGRAM NAME]
- What will be done, where, and for whom: [PLAIN-LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION]
- Number served: [NUM PARTICIPANTS]
- Delivery model: [DELIVERY MODEL]
- Key sites/partners: [SITES/PARTNERS]

Request & Budget:
- Amount requested: [$AMOUNT]
- Purpose of funds: [PURPOSE]
- Grant period: [TIMEFRAME]
- Total project/program budget: [$TOTAL BUDGET]
- Confirmed/matching/leveraged funds: [MATCH/LEVERAGE]
- Per-participant cost (if applicable): [$COST PER PARTICIPANT]

Outcomes (3–5 measurable results with targets + timing):
[OUTCOMES – e.g., “Serve 250 youth; 85% on-time graduation within 12 months.”]

Evidence & Evaluation:
- Prior results or research base: [EVIDENCE]
- How results will be tracked: [EVALUATION APPROACH – e.g., “quarterly surveys, case records, database reports”]

Organizational Capacity:
- Track record/years operating/people served: [QUALIFICATIONS]
- Staffing/governance highlights: [STAFFING/GOVERNANCE]
- Fiscal health (if strong): [FISCAL STATUS – e.g., “clean audits, 6-month reserves”]

Funder Alignment:
- Funder priority phrases (use 1–2 explicitly): [FUNDER PRIORITY PHRASES]
- How your work connects: [ALIGNMENT STATEMENT]

Equity & Community Voice:
- Who benefits (demographics, barriers addressed): [EQUITY]
- Community input in design: [COMMUNITY INPUT]
- Access considerations (language, transportation, cultural responsiveness): [ACCESS]

Timeline (3–4 milestones):
[TIMELINE MILESTONES – e.g., “Months 1–2: hire staff; Months 3–6: enroll 100 participants; Month 9: midpoint evaluation; Month 12: final report.”]

Sustainability:
- How work continues post-grant (diversified funding, earned revenue, policy alignment, committed funders): [SUSTAINABILITY]

Contact Information:
- Contact (for questions; usually program/development staff): [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]
- Signer (only if funder requires; usually ED/CEO): [SIGNER NAME, TITLE]

STEP 3: CONTENT REQUIREMENTS (GENERATE THE EXECUTIVE SUMMARY)

Length:
- 250–400 words total.

Structure & Format:
- Use micro-headings for skimming, in this order: Need, Solution, Request, Outcomes, Evidence & Evaluation, Organizational Capacity, Funder Fit, Equity & Community Voice, Timeline, Sustainability, Contact
- Each section = 1 short paragraph of 2–3 sentences maximum
- Bold the funding request amount and 2–3 key metrics/targets
- Define acronyms on first use
- Use active voice; plain language; avoid jargon and superlatives
- Output as formatted text ready to paste into a Word document (clear section breaks)
- Adjust sections based on funder RFP; if space is tight, prioritize: Need → Solution → Request → Outcomes → Capacity

Content Priorities:
1) Need (1–2 sentences): Name the community, scale of need, who is most affected, and specific impact. Be concrete and local.
2) Solution (2–3 sentences): What will be done, for whom, where, and how many will be served; include delivery model and key partners.
3) Request (1–2 sentences): State prominently: [AMOUNT] for [PURPOSE] over [TIMEFRAME]; include total budget, confirmed/matching funds, and per-participant cost if relevant.
4) Outcomes (2–3 sentences): Provide 3–5 measurable outcomes with targets and timing.
5) Evidence & Evaluation (1–2 sentences): Cite prior results or research and how results will be tracked.
6) Organizational Capacity (1–2 sentences): Track record, staffing/governance, fiscal health.
7) Funder Fit (1 sentence): Explicitly align with [FUNDER NAME] priorities using their language once or twice (no overdoing it).
8) Equity & Community Voice (1–2 sentences): Who benefits, community input, and access considerations.
9) Timeline (1 sentence or short list): 3–4 milestones.
10) Sustainability (1 sentence): How work continues after the grant.
11) Contact (1 line): Brief invitation + contact details; include signer only if required.

Quality Standards:
DO:
- Be concrete and numeric (e.g., “served 450 families,” “92% retained housing”)
- Use funder’s priority language (accurately, 1–2 times)
- Lead with impact; make every sentence advance need, solution, or evidence
- Use specific place names and populations
- Keep paragraphs tight and focused

DON’T:
- Use clichés (“transformational,” “world-class,” “cutting-edge,” “game-changing”)
- Restate your mission statement
- Introduce ideas not in the full proposal
- Use undefined acronyms or jargon
- Make vague claims without data
- Write in passive voice
- Exceed 400 words

EXAMPLE SNIPPET (Need + Solution opening):
“In Riverside County, 1 in 4 seniors over 75 lives alone without regular social contact, contributing to cognitive decline and premature institutionalization. The Senior Companionship Project will provide evidence-based peer support to 150 isolated seniors across 12 rural townships, matching trained volunteers for weekly in-home visits, monthly group activities, and coordinated referrals with local health providers.”

Now generate the executive summary using the information provided above.

scenarios.name: Small Community Org
scenarios.description: Neighborhood-based immigrant services nonprofit in urban Oakland seeking a family foundation grant for ESOL-to-employment programming.

values.PURPOSE \u2013 e.g., \u201cgeneral opera: workforce ESOL and job placement program
values.GEOGRAPHY \u2013 city/county/region: Oakland’s Fruitvale and San Antonio neighborhoods, Alameda County, CA
values.POPULATION \u2013 be specific: Low-income Latinx and Mam-speaking Guatemalan immigrants ages 18–55
values.DELIVERY MODEL \u2013 e.g., \u201cweekly: Evening ESOL classes twice weekly, 1:1 career coaching, employer-led mock interviews
values.SITES/PARTNERS: Oakland Adult & Career Education; Peralta Colleges; Goodwill of the East Bay; La Clínica de La Raza (referrals); local employers (Durable Goods Co., FreshGrocer)
values.MATCH/LEVERAGE: $40,000 City of Oakland Workforce Board; $20,000 individual donors; $5,000 in-kind classroom space
values.GEOGRAPHY: Fruitvale and San Antonio neighborhoods, Oakland, CA
values.POPULATION: Recently arrived Latinx and Indigenous (Mam-speaking) immigrants with limited English proficiency
values.KEY DATA POINTS: 41% of adults in Fruitvale speak English “less than very well” (ACS 2019–2023); unemployment among recent immigrants is 9.8% vs 4.3% citywide; entry-level wages average $19.50/hour while Bay Area living wage for a single parent with one child is $47.29/hour
values.IMPACT DESCRIPTION: Limited English and lack of networks keep newcomers in unstable, low-wage jobs without benefits; families face housing cost burdens and food insecurity.
values.PLAIN-LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: We help adult immigrants learn workplace English and land steady jobs. Participants attend evening classes, meet 1:1 with a coach, earn OSHA and food handler cards, and connect to employers ready to hire.
values.DELIVERY MODEL: Evening ESOL classes twice weekly, 1:1 career coaching, employer-led mock interviews
values.PURPOSE: workforce ESOL and job placement program
values.OUTCOMES \u2013 e.g., \u201cServe 250 yo: Serve 50 adults; 80% complete 60+ hours of instruction within 6 months; 65% obtain new or better employment within 6 months; median starting wage of $22/hour; 75% retain employment at 90 days.
values.EVIDENCE: Blend of evidence-based contextualized ESOL and sector-based placement; prior cohort (2024) saw 70% job placement and average wage gain of $3.75/hour.
values.EVALUATION APPROACH \u2013 e.g., \u201cq: Pre/post CASAS language assessments, coaching case notes, employer verification, and 30/90-day follow-up surveys in Spanish and Mam.
values.QUALIFICATIONS: Founded 2016; served 1,800 immigrants across education, legal navigation, and benefits access; 5 program staff with bilingual capacity.
values.STAFFING/GOVERNANCE: TESOL-certified Program Manager; two credentialed ESOL instructors; three career coaches; 11-member community board including former participants.
values.FISCAL STATUS \u2013 e.g., \u201cclean a: Balanced budgets, on-time reporting to city contracts, 2.5 months operating reserves.
values.FUNDER PRIORITY PHRASES: economic mobility; immigrant and refugee integration
values.ALIGNMENT STATEMENT: E2E directly advances economic mobility for immigrant and refugee families by pairing language acquisition with job placement.
values.EQUITY: Centers Latinx and Indigenous newcomers facing language, documentation, and discrimination barriers; services offered regardless of status.
values.COMMUNITY INPUT: Curriculum topics and class times set through quarterly participant councils and SMS polls.
values.ACCESS: Classes in Spanish and Mam; evening schedule near AC Transit lines; childcare and transit vouchers provided; culturally responsive coaching.
values.TIMELINE MILESTONES \u2013 e.g., \u201cM: Months 1–2: recruit and enroll 50 participants; Months 3–8: instruction and certifications; Month 6: employer hiring fair; Month 9: 90-day employment follow-ups; Month 12: final evaluation and report.
values.SUSTAINABILITY: Sustained through City workforce contract renewals, employer sponsorships, individual donors, and alignment with state Adult Education (WIOA) funding.
values.TITLE: Executive Director

scenarios.name: Mid-Size Professional Org
scenarios.description: Regional conservation nonprofit serving rural Appalachian communities, seeking an institutional funder for measurable water quality improvements.

values.PURPOSE \u2013 e.g., \u201cgeneral opera: implementation of on-farm best management practices to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution
values.GEOGRAPHY \u2013 city/county/region: Monongahela and Youghiogheny River watersheds—Fayette and Greene Counties, PA, and Monongalia County, WV
values.POPULATION \u2013 be specific: Family farmers and rural residents reliant on private wells and local waterways
values.DELIVERY MODEL \u2013 e.g., \u201cweekly: Farm assessments, cost-share grants, technical assistance, and quarterly water quality monitoring
values.SITES/PARTNERS: Penn State Extension; County Conservation Districts; WVU Water Research Institute; Trout Unlimited chapters; local equipment suppliers
values.MATCH/LEVERAGE: $300,000 USDA NRCS EQIP cost-share; $150,000 county conservation funds; $50,000 private donors; $25,000 in-kind lab analysis
values.GEOGRAPHY: Monongahela and Youghiogheny River watersheds in PA/WV
values.POPULATION: Family farmers and rural households using private wells
values.KEY DATA POINTS: 40% of tested stream miles impaired for aquatic life (PA DEP 2024); 18% of private wells exceed 10 mg/L nitrate; agriculture identified as leading sediment source.
values.IMPACT DESCRIPTION: Degraded water quality harms farm productivity, raises household health risks, and reduces recreation and tourism revenues.
values.PLAIN-LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: We help farms keep manure and soil out of streams by installing fencing, stream crossings, cover crops, and manure storage, coupled with training and water testing.
values.DELIVERY MODEL: Farm assessments, cost-share grants, technical assistance, and quarterly water quality monitoring
values.PURPOSE: implementation of on-farm best management practices to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution
values.OUTCOMES \u2013 e.g., \u201cServe 250 yo: Enroll 120 farms; install 280 BMP projects; reduce nitrogen loads by 75,000 lbs and sediment by 1,500 tons annually; document a 15% improvement in macroinvertebrate scores at 8 monitoring sites within 12 months.
values.EVIDENCE: USDA and Chesapeake Bay Program research show BMPs reduce nutrient and sediment loads; 2023 pilot with 35 farms achieved 20% nitrate reductions downstream.
values.EVALUATION APPROACH \u2013 e.g., \u201cq: Quarterly grab samples and continuous sensors; GIS-tracked BMP installs; farmer adoption surveys; independent lab verification.
values.QUALIFICATIONS: Founded 2003; protected 22,000 acres and restored 65 stream miles; staff of 24 including 8 certified conservation planners.
values.STAFFING/GOVERNANCE: Program Director is a Professional Engineer; board includes hydrologists, farmers, and county officials; strong finance and compliance team.
values.FISCAL STATUS \u2013 e.g., \u201cclean a: Clean single audits for 6 consecutive years; 5-month operating reserves; federally approved indirect cost rate.
values.FUNDER PRIORITY PHRASES: measurable water quality improvements; community resilience
values.ALIGNMENT STATEMENT: The Initiative delivers measurable water quality improvements while strengthening rural community resilience through farm viability.
values.EQUITY: Cost-share prioritizes small and historically underserved producers; outreach via Grange halls and farm bureaus; Spanish-language materials for dairy workers.
values.COMMUNITY INPUT: Project sites selected with a farmer advisory group and township listening sessions.
values.ACCESS: Field staff travel to farms; evening workshops; stipends for time and fuel; plain-language materials.
values.TIMELINE MILESTONES \u2013 e.g., \u201cM: Q1: site assessments and contracts; Q2–Q3: BMP installation; Q3: mid-year monitoring report; Q4: post-install sampling and final report.
values.SUSTAINABILITY: Ongoing NRCS and state agriculture funding, a revolving cost-share fund from repayments, and landowner maintenance agreements for 10+ years.
values.TITLE: Executive Director

scenarios.name: Large Established Org
scenarios.description: Countywide housing nonprofit in Los Angeles partnering with a national foundation to scale family homelessness diversion.

values.PURPOSE \u2013 e.g., \u201cgeneral opera: family homelessness diversion and rapid resolution
values.GEOGRAPHY \u2013 city/county/region: Los Angeles County, focusing on Service Planning Areas (SPAs) 2, 4, and 6
values.POPULATION \u2013 be specific: Families at imminent risk of homelessness, predominantly Black and Latino single mothers with children under 12
values.DELIVERY MODEL \u2013 e.g., \u201cweekly: Diversion screening at Coordinated Entry, mediation with landlords/family, flexible financial assistance, and 1:1 housing stabilization coaching
values.SITES/PARTNERS: LAHSA Coordinated Entry System; DPSS CalWORKs offices; Neighborhood Legal Services; 211 LA; school district McKinney-Vento liaisons
values.MATCH/LEVERAGE: $3,000,000 LA County Measure H; $1,250,000 private donors/corporate partners; $500,000 in-kind hotel vouchers and pro bono legal services
values.POPULATION: Families with minor children at risk of entering shelter, disproportionately Black and Latino single-mother households
values.KEY DATA POINTS: 2024 LAHSA count: 28,458 people in families experienced homelessness in past year; 69% of family heads are women; average 2BR rent $2,781/month while median CalWORKs grant for a family of three is $1,233.
values.IMPACT DESCRIPTION: A shelter entry often disrupts work and school, deepens trauma, and increases time to permanent housing.
values.PLAIN-LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION: We stop a shelter stay before it starts. Trained specialists help families solve immediate housing crises through mediation, short-term cash for rent or utilities, and intensive problem-solving with follow-up coaching.
values.DELIVERY MODEL: Diversion screening at Coordinated Entry, mediation with landlords/family, flexible financial assistance, and 1:1 housing stabilization coaching
values.PURPOSE: family homelessness diversion and rapid resolution
values.OUTCOMES \u2013 e.g., \u201cServe 250 yo: Divert 1,200 families from shelter; 85% remain stably housed at 6 months; 70% sustain housing at 12 months; average assistance per family under $2,200; reduce average time to resolution to 10 days.
values.EVIDENCE: Diversion models in King County and LA County show 70–80% housing retention with flexible assistance; MFHP’s 2023 pilot diverted 410 families with 83% 6‑month stability.
values.EVALUATION APPROACH \u2013 e.g., \u201cq: HMIS data pulls, case records, landlord verification, and 6- and 12-month follow-up surveys; quarterly dashboard reviews.
values.QUALIFICATIONS: Established 1988; served 18,000 people last year across prevention, shelter, and housing; 220 staff and countywide footprint.
values.STAFFING/GOVERNANCE: Led by an LCSW-run Housing Stabilization team; multilingual navigators; HMIS data team; board includes healthcare and housing finance leaders plus lived-experience advisors.
values.FISCAL STATUS \u2013 e.g., \u201cclean a: Unmodified audits for 10 years; 6-month operating reserves; strong government contract management.
values.ALIGNMENT STATEMENT: This Initiative advances family homelessness prevention by resolving crises upstream, aligning with Hilton’s focus on solutions that keep families housed.
values.EQUITY: Targets SPAs with highest rates of Black family homelessness; culturally responsive services; flexible aid removes barriers for undocumented caregivers.
values.COMMUNITY INPUT: Design informed by a parent advisory council and feedback from school McKinney-Vento liaisons.
values.ACCESS: Walk-in sites near transit; extended evening hours; services in English and Spanish; childcare and Lyft rides for appointments.
values.TIMELINE MILESTONES \u2013 e.g., \u201cM: Months 1–3: hire and train 12 diversion specialists; Months 4–24: operate diversion services countywide; Month 12: midpoint evaluation; Month 24: final report and knowledge-sharing brief.
values.SUSTAINABILITY: Post-grant support through Measure H renewal, Medi-Cal Community Supports partnerships, and committed private co-investors.
values.TITLE: Chief Executive Officer

outputs.content:
**English to Employment (E2E) Program**

**Need**
Oakland’s Fruitvale and San Antonio neighborhoods are home to many recently arrived Latinx and Indigenous (Mam-speaking) immigrants. A significant 41% of adults in Fruitvale speak English "less than very well," contributing to a 9.8% unemployment rate among recent immigrants, far exceeding the citywide average. This lack of English proficiency and limited networks forces newcomers into unstable, low-wage jobs, leading to housing burdens and food insecurity for families.

**Solution**
Our English to Employment (E2E) program empowers adult immigrants to learn workplace English and secure steady employment. We will serve **50 participants** with evening ESOL classes offered twice weekly, paired with 1:1 career coaching, industry certifications like OSHA and food handler cards, and direct connections to local employers ready to hire. Key partners include Oakland Adult & Career Education, Peralta Colleges, and local employers like Durable Goods Co. and FreshGrocer.

**Request**
We request **$45,000** from the Larkin Family Foundation to support the English to Employment (E2E) workforce ESOL and job placement program from July 2025 – June 2026. The total program budget is $120,000, with $40,000 confirmed from the City of Oakland Workforce Board, $20,000 from individual donors, and $5,000 in-kind classroom space. The estimated per-participant cost is $2,400.

**Outcomes**
E2E aims to serve 50 adults, with **80% completing 60+ hours of instruction** within 6 months. We target **65% obtaining new or better employment** within 6 months, achieving a median starting wage of **$22/hour**, and 75% retaining employment at 90 days.

**Evidence & Evaluation**
Our approach blends evidence-based contextualized ESOL with sector-based placement. A prior cohort (2024) saw a 70% job placement rate and an average wage gain of $3.75/hour. Results will be tracked through pre/post CASAS language assessments, coaching case notes, employer verification, and 30/90-day follow-up surveys in Spanish and Mam.

**Organizational Capacity**
Fruitvale Community Bridge, founded in 2016, has served 1,800 immigrants through education, legal navigation, and benefits access. Our 5 program staff are bilingual and include TESOL-certified and credentialed instructors and career coaches. We maintain balanced budgets, deliver on-time reporting for city contracts, and have 2.5 months of operating reserves.

**Funder Fit**
This program directly aligns with the Larkin Family Foundation’s commitment to **economic mobility** and **immigrant and refugee integration**.

**Equity & Community Voice**
E2E centers Latinx and Indigenous newcomers facing language, documentation, and discrimination barriers, offering services regardless of immigration status. Curriculum topics and class times are set through quarterly participant councils and SMS polls, with classes offered in Spanish and Mam, an evening schedule near transit lines, and provision of childcare and transit vouchers.

**Timeline**
Months 1–2: recruit and enroll 50 participants; Months 3–8: instruction and certifications; Month 6: employer hiring fair; Month 9: 90-day employment follow-ups; Month 12: final evaluation and report.

**Sustainability**
The E2E program will be sustained through City workforce contract renewals, employer sponsorships, individual donors, and alignment with state Adult Education (WIOA) funding.

**Contact**
[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]

evaluation.reasoning: The output is structurally sound and includes most required elements with accurate data, but it fails to match the requested CASUAL tone (reading as FORMAL instead), omits the contact details in the final section, and uses some stiff phrasing that undermines authenticity for a small community org writing to a family foundation.
strengths: Excellent use of bolding for key metrics ($45,000, 80% completion, 65% employment, $22/hour) making them scannable
Strong concrete data throughout (41% English proficiency stat, 9.8% vs 4.3% unemployment, $3.75/hour wage gain from prior cohort)
Clear structure with micro-headings that aid skimming and follows the prescribed order
Accurate representation of all numerical data and program details from the scenario
Good integration of funder priority language ('economic mobility' and 'immigrant and refugee integration') without overuse
Stays within word count (approximately 380 words)
Equity section effectively addresses language access, immigration status, and community input
weaknesses: CRITICAL: Tone mismatch—requested CASUAL but delivered FORMAL. Phrases like 'A significant 41%' and 'empowers adult immigrants' are institutional, not plainspoken for a relationship-based funder
Contact section incomplete—shows placeholder '[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]' instead of actual details (Marisol Vega, Executive Director, mvega@fruitvalebridge.org, (510) 555-0134)
Missing the signer information (Ana Lucero) which was provided in the scenario data
Some robotic phrasing: 'empowers adult immigrants' and 'centers Latinx and Indigenous newcomers' sound like grant-speak rather than authentic voice
Need section could be tighter—combines stats in ways that feel list-like rather than narrative
Missed opportunity to make the casual tone come through with more direct, conversational language (e.g., 'We help people get better jobs' vs 'empowers adult immigrants to secure steady employment')

outputs.content:
# EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

**Need**  
In Oakland's Fruitvale and San Antonio neighborhoods, 41% of adults speak English "less than very well," and unemployment among recent immigrants is 9.8%—more than double the citywide rate. Limited English and lack of networks keep recently arrived Latinx and Mam-speaking Guatemalan immigrants in unstable, low-wage jobs without benefits, while Bay Area living costs continue to climb.

**Solution**  
English to Employment (E2E) helps adult immigrants learn workplace English and land steady jobs. **50 participants** attend evening ESOL classes twice weekly, meet 1:1 with career coaches, earn OSHA and food handler certifications, and connect with local employers ready to hire. We partner with Oakland Adult & Career Education, Peralta Colleges, Goodwill of the East Bay, La Clínica de La Raza, and employers including Durable Goods Co. and FreshGrocer.

**Request**  
Fruitvale Community Bridge requests **$45,000** from the Larkin Family Foundation to support E2E from July 2025 through June 2026. The total project budget is $120,000, with $40,000 confirmed from the City of Oakland Workforce Board, $20,000 from individual donors, and $5,000 in-kind classroom space. Cost per participant is $2,400.

**Outcomes**  
We will serve **50 adults**; **80% will complete 60+ hours** of instruction within 6 months; **65% will obtain new or better employment** within 6 months with a median starting wage of **$22/hour**; and 75% will retain employment at 90 days.

**Evidence & Evaluation**  
E2E blends evidence-based contextualized ESOL with sector-based job placement; our 2024 cohort achieved 70% job placement and average wage gains of $3.75/hour. We track results using pre/post CASAS language assessments, coaching case notes, employer verification, and 30/90-day follow-up surveys in Spanish and Mam.

**Organizational Capacity**  
Founded in 2016, we've served 1,800 immigrants across education, legal navigation, and benefits access. Our team includes a TESOL-certified Program Manager, two credentialed ESOL instructors, three career coaches, and an 11-member community board with former participants. We maintain balanced budgets, on-time city contract reporting, and 2.5 months operating reserves.

**Funder Fit**  
E2E directly advances economic mobility for immigrant and refugee families by pairing language acquisition with job placement, aligning closely with Larkin Family Foundation priorities.

**Equity & Community Voice**  
E2E centers Latinx and Indigenous newcomers facing language, documentation, and discrimination barriers, serving participants regardless of status. Curriculum topics and class times are set through quarterly participant councils and SMS polls; classes are offered in Spanish and Mam with evening schedules near transit, plus childcare and transit vouchers.

**Timeline**  
Months 1–2: recruit and enroll 50 participants; Months 3–8: instruction and certifications; Month 6: employer hiring fair; Month 9: 90-day employment follow-ups; Month 12: final evaluation and report.

**Sustainability**  
E2E will continue through City workforce contract renewals, employer sponsorships, individual donors, and alignment with state Adult Education (WIOA) funding.

**Contact**  
Questions welcome: [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]

---

**Word count: 398**

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, usable executive summary that successfully balances professionalism with the requested casual tone. It includes concrete data, clear outcomes, and appropriate formatting. However, it has a critical error in the contact section and slightly exceeds best-practice length for maximum impact.
strengths: Excellent use of concrete data and metrics throughout (41% speak English 'less than very well,' 9.8% unemployment, $22/hour median wage, 70% prior placement rate)
Strong casual tone that remains professional—uses accessible language like 'land steady jobs' and 'employers ready to hire' without being unprofessional
Effective bolding of key numbers (50 participants, 80% completion, 65% employment, $22/hour, $45,000) for easy scanning
Well-structured with clear micro-headings that follow the template exactly, making it highly skimmable
Authentic community voice—mentions Mam language, participant councils, SMS polls, and 'regardless of status' which shows cultural competency
Strong funder alignment statement that explicitly uses the foundation's priority language ('economic mobility,' 'immigrant and refugee')
Excellent specificity in partnerships and geography (names actual employers, transit lines, neighborhoods)
Compelling evidence section that cites prior results (70% placement, $3.75/hour wage gain) and clear evaluation methods
weaknesses: Critical error: Contact section shows placeholder text '[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]' instead of actual contact information (Marisol Vega, Executive Director, mvega@fruitvalebridge.org, (510) 555-0134)
At 398 words, it's at the upper limit—could be tightened to 350 words for stronger impact by condensing Organizational Capacity or combining Timeline with Outcomes
Minor: Does not include the signer (Ana Lucero) even though provided in the input, though the prompt notes this is 'only if funder requires'
The Funder Fit section is somewhat generic—could be strengthened by mentioning a specific Larkin Family Foundation program area or past grant if known

outputs.content:
Need
In Oakland’s Fruitvale and San Antonio neighborhoods, many recently arrived Latinx and Mam-speaking Guatemalan adults struggle to find steady work due to limited English and few networks. Here, 41% of adults speak English “less than very well,” recent-immigrant unemployment is 9.8% vs 4.3% citywide, and entry wages (~$19.50/hour) lag far below the $47.29 living wage for a single parent—driving rent burden and food insecurity.

Solution
English to Employment (E2E) helps 50 low-income immigrant adults in Fruitvale and San Antonio learn workplace English and connect to jobs. We offer evening English for Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL) classes twice weekly, 1:1 career coaching, employer-led mock interviews, and industry credentials (Occupational Safety and Health Administration [OSHA] 10 and food handler cards). Partners include Oakland Adult & Career Education, Peralta Colleges, Goodwill of the East Bay, La Clínica de La Raza (referrals), and hiring employers like Durable Goods Co. and FreshGrocer.

Request
We request **$45,000** from the Larkin Family Foundation for our workforce ESOL and job placement program from July 2025–June 2026. The total program budget is $120,000, with $40,000 confirmed from the City of Oakland Workforce Board, $20,000 from individual donors, and $5,000 in-kind classroom space; per-participant cost is $2,400.

Outcomes
We will **serve 50 adults** and ensure 80% complete 60+ hours of instruction within six months. At least **65% obtain new or better employment within six months** at a **median starting wage of $22/hour**, and 75% retain employment at 90 days.

Evidence & Evaluation
E2E blends evidence-based, contextualized ESOL with sector-focused placement; our 2024 cohort achieved 70% job placement and a $3.75/hour average wage gain. We track results via pre/post Comprehensive Adult Student Assessment Systems (CASAS) language tests, coaching notes, employer verification, and 30/90-day follow-up surveys in Spanish and Mam.

Organizational Capacity
Founded in 2016, Fruitvale Community Bridge has served 1,800 immigrants across education, legal navigation, and benefits access. Our TESOL-certified Program Manager, two credentialed ESOL instructors, and three career coaches are backed by an 11-member community board; we maintain balanced budgets, on-time city reporting, and 2.5 months of operating reserves.

Funder Fit
E2E advances Larkin’s priorities around economic mobility and immigrant and refugee integration by pairing language learning with real job placement in Oakland.

Equity & Community Voice
We center Latinx and Indigenous newcomers, serving all regardless of status. Participants shape curriculum and class times through quarterly councils and SMS polls; classes are in Spanish and Mam, near AC Transit lines, with childcare, transit vouchers, and culturally responsive coaching.

Timeline
Months 1–2: recruit/enroll 50; Months 3–8: instruction and OSHA/food handler certifications; Month 6: employer hiring fair; Month 9: 90-day employment follow-ups; Month 12: final evaluation and report.

Sustainability
We will continue through City workforce contract renewals, employer sponsorships, individual donors, and alignment with state Adult Education funding under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA).

Contact
Questions welcome: [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]. Signer (if required): [SIGNER NAME, TITLE].

outputs.content:
Here is the executive summary for the Allegheny Watershed Conservancy:

### Executive Summary

**Need**
The Monongahela and Youghiogheny River watersheds in Pennsylvania and West Virginia face significant water quality degradation, critically impacting family farmers and rural households. Forty percent of tested stream miles are impaired for aquatic life (PA DEP 2024), 18% of private wells exceed the 10 mg/L nitrate standard, and agriculture is identified as the leading sediment source. This directly harms farm productivity, raises household health risks, and reduces vital recreation and tourism revenues.

**Solution**
The Allegheny Watershed Conservancy’s Healthy Streams Initiative will implement on-farm best management practices (BMPs) to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution. Serving 120 family farms across Fayette and Greene Counties (PA) and Monongalia County (WV), this program utilizes farm assessments, cost-share grants, technical assistance, and quarterly water quality monitoring. Key partners include Penn State Extension, County Conservation Districts, the WVU Water Research Institute, and local Trout Unlimited chapters.

**Request**
We request **$250,000** from the Appalachian Stewardship Foundation for the implementation of on-farm best management practices to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution during the January–December 2026 grant period. The total project budget is $850,000, with $300,000 in USDA NRCS EQIP cost-share, $150,000 from county conservation funds, $50,000 from private donors, and $25,000 in-kind lab analysis already confirmed. The estimated per-participant cost is $7,083.

**Outcomes**
Within 12 months, the Initiative will enroll 120 farms, install **280 BMP projects**, reduce nitrogen loads by **75,000 lbs** and sediment by **1,500 tons annually**, and document a 15% improvement in macroinvertebrate scores at 8 monitoring sites.

**Evidence & Evaluation**
Research from the USDA and Chesapeake Bay Program substantiates the efficacy of BMPs in reducing nutrient and sediment loads; a 2023 pilot with 35 farms demonstrated a 20% reduction in downstream nitrate levels. Results will be tracked through quarterly grab samples, continuous sensors, GIS-tracked BMP installations, farmer adoption surveys, and independent laboratory verification.

**Organizational Capacity**
Established in 2003, the Allegheny Watershed Conservancy has protected 22,000 acres and restored 65 stream miles, operating with a staff of 24, including 8 certified conservation planners. Our Program Director is a Professional Engineer, our board includes hydrologists and farmers, and we maintain strong fiscal health with clean single audits for six consecutive years and a 5-month operating reserve.

**Funder Fit**
This Initiative directly delivers measurable water quality improvements and strengthens rural community resilience, aligning with the Appalachian Stewardship Foundation’s priorities.

**Equity & Community Voice**
Cost-share opportunities prioritize small and historically underserved producers, with outreach conducted through local Grange halls and farm bureaus, and Spanish-language materials provided for dairy workers. Project sites were selected with a farmer advisory group and input from township listening sessions.

**Timeline**
Q1: site assessments and contracts finalized; Q2–Q3: BMP installation; Q3: mid-year monitoring report; Q4: post-installation sampling and final report.

**Sustainability**
Post-grant sustainability is ensured through ongoing USDA NRCS and state agriculture funding, a revolving cost-share fund from producer repayments, and landowner maintenance agreements spanning 10+ years.

**Contact**
For questions, please contact [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE].

The content quality is professional and data-rich, but these technical failures reduce practical utility.
strengths: Excellent formal tone appropriate for institutional funders, with precise technical language and no inappropriate superlatives or clichés
Strong use of concrete data and metrics throughout (40% impaired streams, 280 BMP projects, 75,000 lbs nitrogen reduction) with appropriate bolding of key figures
Well-structured with clear micro-headings that enable easy skimming and logical flow from need through sustainability
Effective integration of funder priority language ('measurable water quality improvements' and 'community resilience') without overuse
Comprehensive partner list and funding leverage clearly articulated, demonstrating organizational capacity and collaborative approach
Strong evidence section citing both research base and pilot results with specific outcomes
weaknesses: Critical error: Contact section shows placeholder text '[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]' instead of actual contact information (Ian McCullough, Executive Director, imccullough@alleghenywc.org, (724) 555-0476)
Significantly exceeds word count requirement: 489 words vs. 250-400 maximum—would require substantial editing before submission
Missing signer information (Dr. Leanne Porter) which was provided in the input data, though prompt indicates this is only needed 'if funder requires'
Some sections could be more concise to meet length requirements—Organizational Capacity and Evidence sections are particularly verbose
The equity section, while present, could more explicitly connect access considerations to outcomes rather than just listing accommodations

outputs.content:
# EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

**Need**  
In the Monongahela and Youghiogheny River watersheds of Fayette and Greene Counties, PA, and Monongalia County, WV, **40% of tested stream miles are impaired for aquatic life** (PA DEP 2024), with agriculture identified as the leading sediment source. Eighteen percent of private wells serving rural households exceed safe nitrate levels, threatening the health of family farmers and rural residents while reducing farm productivity and recreation revenues.

**Solution**  
The Healthy Streams Initiative will help **120 farms** keep manure and soil out of streams by installing livestock fencing, stream crossings, cover crops, and manure storage facilities, coupled with training and water quality testing. Allegheny Watershed Conservancy will deliver farm assessments, cost-share grants, technical assistance, and quarterly water quality monitoring in partnership with Penn State Extension, County Conservation Districts, WVU Water Research Institute, Trout Unlimited chapters, and local equipment suppliers.

**Request**  
We request **$250,000** to support implementation of on-farm best management practices (BMPs) to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution from January through December 2026. The total project budget is **$850,000**, leveraging **$525,000** in confirmed matching funds from USDA NRCS EQIP cost-share ($300,000), county conservation programs ($150,000), private donors ($50,000), and in-kind lab analysis ($25,000), for a per-farm investment of $7,083.

**Outcomes**  
The Initiative will enroll 120 farms; install **280 BMP projects**; reduce nitrogen loads by **75,000 lbs** and sediment by **1,500 tons annually**; and document a **15% improvement in macroinvertebrate scores** at 8 monitoring sites within 12 months of project completion.

**Evidence & Evaluation**  
USDA and Chesapeake Bay Program research confirm BMPs reduce nutrient and sediment loads; our 2023 pilot with 35 farms achieved 20% downstream nitrate reductions. Results will be tracked through quarterly grab samples, continuous sensors, GIS-tracked BMP installations, farmer adoption surveys, and independent lab verification.

**Organizational Capacity**  
Founded in 2003, Allegheny Watershed Conservancy has protected 22,000 acres and restored 65 stream miles with a staff of 24 including 8 certified conservation planners. Our Program Director is a Professional Engineer; the board includes hydrologists, farmers, and county officials; and we maintain clean single audits, 5-month operating reserves, and a federally approved indirect cost rate.

**Funder Fit**  
This Initiative delivers measurable water quality improvements while strengthening community resilience through enhanced farm viability—priorities central to Appalachian Stewardship Foundation's mission.

**Equity & Community Voice**  
Cost-share prioritizes small and historically underserved producers identified through farmer advisory groups and township listening sessions. Field staff travel to farms for evening workshops, provide stipends for time and fuel, and offer Spanish-language materials for dairy workers.

**Timeline**  
Q1: site assessments and contracts; Q2–Q3: BMP installation; Q3: mid-year monitoring report; Q4: post-install sampling and final report.

**Sustainability**  
Ongoing NRCS and state agriculture funding, a revolving cost-share fund from repayments, and landowner maintenance agreements ensure work continues for 10+ years.

**Contact**  
We welcome your questions: [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, professional executive summary that effectively communicates a complex environmental project with appropriate formality and concrete metrics. The structure is clear, the data is compelling, and the writing is crisp. However, it has minor completeness issues (missing contact details in final line) and occasionally feels slightly formulaic in transitions between sections.
strengths: Excellent use of bold formatting on key metrics (40%, 120 farms, $250,000, 280 BMP projects, 75,000 lbs, 1,500 tons, 15% improvement) that makes the summary highly scannable
Strong formal tone with technical precision appropriate for institutional funder—uses proper terminology (macroinvertebrate scores, EQIP, BMPs) without being inaccessible
Compelling need statement with specific, credible data (PA DEP 2024, 40% impaired streams, 18% wells exceeding nitrate) that establishes urgency without hyperbole
Excellent demonstration of leverage—clearly shows $250K request unlocks $525K in matching funds, making the 3:1 match ratio immediately apparent
Well-integrated funder alignment that uses their exact language ('measurable water quality improvements' and 'community resilience') naturally rather than awkwardly
Strong equity section that goes beyond boilerplate—Spanish materials for dairy workers, stipends for time/fuel, and farmer advisory groups show genuine access considerations
Concrete outcomes with specific targets and timelines that are measurable and realistic
Stays within word count (approximately 380 words) while covering all required sections
weaknesses: Contact section incomplete—shows placeholder '[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]' instead of actual details (Ian McCullough, Executive Director, imccullough@alleghenywc.org, (724) 555-0476) provided in the scenario
Missing signer information (Dr. Leanne Porter) which was provided and may be expected by some institutional funders
Timeline section could be slightly more specific—'Q2–Q3: BMP installation' is a 6-month window that could benefit from more granular milestones
The transition between sections occasionally feels mechanical—each paragraph stands alone well but there's minimal narrative flow connecting them
Evidence section could strengthen the pilot results claim—'20% nitrate reductions downstream' from 35 farms is compelling but doesn't specify measurement period or methodology

outputs.content:
Need
In the Monongahela and Youghiogheny River watersheds (Fayette and Greene Counties, PA, and Monongalia County, WV), family farmers and rural households using private wells face degraded water quality: 40% of tested stream miles are impaired for aquatic life (Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection, PA DEP, 2024), and 18% of private wells exceed 10 mg/L nitrate, with agriculture the leading sediment source. These conditions undercut farm productivity, elevate household health risks, and dampen recreation and tourism revenues.

Solution
The Healthy Streams Initiative will help 120 farms keep manure and soil out of streams by installing best management practices (BMPs)—fencing, stream crossings, cover crops, and manure storage—paired with training and quarterly water testing. Delivery includes farm assessments, cost-share grants, and technical assistance in partnership with Penn State Extension, County Conservation Districts, the West Virginia University (WVU) Water Research Institute, Trout Unlimited chapters, and local suppliers.

Request
Allegheny Watershed Conservancy requests **$250,000** for implementation of on-farm BMPs to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution from January–December 2026. The total program budget is $850,000, with $300,000 U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) cost-share, $150,000 county conservation funds, $50,000 private donors, and $25,000 in-kind lab analysis; estimated cost per participant is $7,083.

Outcomes
By December 2026, we will **enroll 120 farms**, **install 280 BMP projects**, and cut annual loads by 75,000 lbs nitrogen and **1,500 tons sediment**. We will document a 15% improvement in macroinvertebrate scores at eight monitoring sites within 12 months. All BMPs and sampling sites will be georeferenced and tracked.

Evidence & Evaluation
USDA and Chesapeake Bay Program research shows farm BMPs measurably reduce nutrient and sediment loads; our 2023 pilot with 35 farms achieved 20% nitrate reductions downstream. We will collect quarterly grab samples, deploy continuous sensors, verify BMPs via GIS, survey farmer adoption, and use independent labs for validation.

Organizational Capacity
Founded in 2003, we have protected 22,000 acres and restored 65 stream miles, with a staff of 24 including eight certified conservation planners led by a Professional Engineer. We maintain clean single audits (six years), a five-month operating reserve, and a federally approved indirect cost rate.

Funder Fit
This Initiative advances the Appalachian Stewardship Foundation’s priorities by delivering measurable water quality improvements and strengthening rural community resilience.

Equity & Community Voice
We prioritize small and historically underserved producers; conduct outreach through Grange halls and farm bureaus; and provide Spanish-language materials for dairy workers, stipends for time and fuel, and evening workshops. A farmer advisory group and township listening sessions guide site selection and design.

Timeline
Q1: site assessments and contracts; Q2–Q3: BMP installation; Q3: mid-year monitoring report; Q4: post-install sampling and final report.

Sustainability
Ongoing NRCS and state agriculture funding, a revolving cost-share fund from repayments, and 10+ year landowner maintenance agreements will sustain results beyond the grant.

Contact
For questions, please contact [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE].

strengths: Excellent formal tone with appropriate technical language (macroinvertebrate scores, georeferenced BMPs, grab samples) that matches the institutional funder context
Strong use of concrete metrics throughout—bolded key numbers (120 farms, 280 projects, 1,500 tons sediment) make impact immediately scannable

outputs.content:
**Metro Family Housing Partnership – Family Diversion & Stability Initiative**

**Executive Summary**

**Need**
Los Angeles County faces a critical family homelessness crisis, with 28,458 people in families experiencing homelessness in the past year. Families with minor children, particularly Black and Latino single-mother households, are disproportionately affected; a median CalWORKs grant ($1,233 for a family of three) falls far short of the average $2,781/month 2-bedroom rent. Shelter entry disrupts work, schooling, and can deepen trauma, increasing the time families remain unhoused.

**Solution**
The Family Diversion & Stability Initiative aims to prevent shelter entry for **1,200 families** at imminent risk of homelessness in Los Angeles County's SPAs 2, 4, and 6. Through diversion screening at LAHSA Coordinated Entry, mediation with landlords/family, flexible financial assistance, and 1:1 housing stabilization coaching, we stop a shelter stay before it starts. Key partners include DPSS CalWORKs offices, Neighborhood Legal Services, and school district McKinney-Vento liaisons.

**Request**
Metro Family Housing Partnership requests **$1,500,000** from the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation for family homelessness diversion and rapid resolution between July 2025 and June 2027. This forms part of a total $6,500,000 project budget, leveraging $3,000,000 from LA County Measure H, $1,250,000 from private donors/corporate partners, and $500,000 in-kind contributions. The estimated per-participant cost is $5,417 per family.

**Outcomes**
We project diverting **1,200 families** from shelter entry, with **85% remaining stably housed at 6 months** and 70% sustaining housing at 12 months. Our goal is to maintain the average assistance per family under $2,200 and reduce the average time to resolution to 10 days.

**Evidence & Evaluation**
Proven diversion models in King County and LA County demonstrate 70–80% housing retention. Metro Family Housing Partnership's 2023 pilot successfully diverted 410 families, achieving an **83% 6-month stability rate**. Results will be meticulously tracked via HMIS data, case records, landlord verification, and 6- and 12-month follow-up surveys, reviewed quarterly.

**Organizational Capacity**
Established in 1988, Metro Family Housing Partnership served 18,000 people last year and boasts 220 staff and a countywide footprint. Our Housing Stabilization team is led by an LCSW, supported by multilingual navigators and a robust HMIS data team. We maintain unmodified audits for 10 years and possess 6-month operating reserves.

**Funder Fit**
This Initiative directly addresses family homelessness by resolving crises upstream, aligning with the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation’s focus on upstream prevention.

**Equity & Community Voice**
Targeting SPAs with the highest rates of Black family homelessness, the Initiative offers culturally responsive services and flexible aid to remove barriers for undocumented caregivers. Program design was informed by a parent advisory council and McKinney-Vento liaisons, with access considerations including walk-in sites, evening hours, multilingual services, childcare, and Lyft rides.

**Timeline**
Months 1–3: hire and train 12 diversion specialists; Months 4–24: operate diversion services countywide; Month 12: midpoint evaluation.

**Sustainability**
Post-grant support will be secured through Measure H renewal, Medi-Cal Community Supports partnerships, and committed private co-investors.

**Contact**
For questions, please contact [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE].

evaluation.reasoning: The output demonstrates strong grant writing fundamentals with appropriate formal tone and clear structure. However, it contains critical errors: the contact information placeholder wasn't filled in, and the word count (467 words) significantly exceeds the required 250-400 word maximum, making it unsuitable for submission without substantial editing.
strengths: Excellent use of bold formatting on key metrics ($1,500,000, 1,200 families, 85% stability rate, 83% pilot success) that makes the summary highly scannable
Strong data integration with specific, compelling statistics (28,458 people, $2,781 rent vs $1,233 CalWORKs grant, $5,417 per family cost)
Effective use of active voice and concrete language throughout, avoiding jargon and clichés as instructed
Well-structured micro-headings that follow the prescribed order and facilitate quick reading
Authentic funder alignment that uses 'upstream prevention' and 'family homelessness' naturally without overuse
Comprehensive equity section that addresses demographics, community input, and specific access considerations
weaknesses: Critical error: Contact section shows placeholder text '[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]' instead of the provided information (Jasmine Lee, CEO, jlee@mfhp.org, (213) 555-0890)
Exceeds word count by 17%: 467 words vs. 250-400 maximum, requiring significant cuts before submission
Timeline section incomplete—omits Month 24 final report milestone that was provided in the input data
Minor redundancy: 'family homelessness' appears in both the Need and Funder Fit sections in similar phrasing
The signer information (Marcus D. Nguyen) was provided but not included, though the prompt indicates it should only appear 'if funder requires'—unclear if Hilton Foundation requires this

outputs.content:
# EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

**Metro Family Housing Partnership**  
Family Diversion & Stability Initiative  
Request to Conrad N. Hilton Foundation: **$1,500,000** | July 2025–June 2027

---

**Need**  
In Los Angeles County, **28,458 people in families** experienced homelessness in the past year, with 69% headed by single mothers. In Service Planning Areas 2, 4, and 6—where Black and Latino families face disproportionate risk—the average two-bedroom rent is $2,781 while the median CalWORKs grant for a family of three is just $1,233. A shelter entry often disrupts work and school, deepens trauma, and increases time to permanent housing.

**Solution**  
The Family Diversion & Stability Initiative stops shelter stays before they start. Trained specialists embedded at the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) Coordinated Entry System, Department of Public Social Services (DPSS) CalWORKs offices, and school district McKinney-Vento liaison sites will serve **1,200 families** through crisis screening, landlord and family mediation, flexible financial assistance, and intensive one-on-one housing stabilization coaching. Partners include Neighborhood Legal Services, 211 LA, and district liaisons countywide.

**Request**  
Metro Family Housing Partnership requests **$1,500,000** over 24 months for family homelessness diversion and rapid resolution. The total project budget is **$6,500,000**, with $3,000,000 confirmed from LA County Measure H, $1,250,000 from private donors and corporate partners, and $500,000 in in-kind hotel vouchers and pro bono legal services. The estimated cost per family is **$5,417**.

**Outcomes**  
We will divert **1,200 families** from shelter; **85%** will remain stably housed at six months; **70%** will sustain housing at 12 months; average assistance per family will remain under **$2,200**; and average time to resolution will be reduced to **10 days**.

**Evidence & Evaluation**  
Diversion models in King County and LA County demonstrate 70–80% housing retention with flexible assistance. Our 2023 pilot diverted 410 families with 83% six-month stability. Results will be tracked through Homeless Management Information System (HMIS) data pulls, case records, landlord verification, and six- and 12-month follow-up surveys, with quarterly dashboard reviews.

**Organizational Capacity**  
Established in 1988, Metro Family Housing Partnership served 18,000 people last year across prevention, shelter, and housing programs. Our 220 staff include a licensed clinical social worker–led Housing Stabilization team, multilingual navigators, and an HMIS data team; our board comprises healthcare and housing finance leaders plus lived-experience advisors. We have maintained unmodified audits for 10 years and hold six months of operating reserves.

**Funder Fit**  
This Initiative advances upstream prevention of family homelessness by resolving crises before shelter entry, directly aligning with the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation's commitment to solutions that keep families housed.

**Equity & Community Voice**  
The Initiative targets SPAs with the highest rates of Black family homelessness and offers culturally responsive services in English and Spanish. Design was informed by a parent advisory council and McKinney-Vento liaison feedback. Walk-in sites near transit, extended evening hours, childcare support, and Lyft rides for appointments remove barriers for undocumented caregivers and working parents.

**Timeline**  
Months 1–3: hire and train 12 diversion specialists; Months 4–24: operate countywide diversion services; Month 12: midpoint evaluation; Month 24: final report and knowledge-sharing brief.

**Sustainability**  
Post-grant support will continue through Measure H renewal, Medi-Cal Community Supports partnerships, and committed private co-investors.

**Contact**  
We welcome questions about the Family Diversion & Stability Initiative.  
[Contact Name, Title | Email | Phone]

---

**Word count: 398**

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, professional executive summary that effectively uses formal nonprofit language, concrete data, and clear structure. It successfully balances comprehensiveness with brevity and would serve well in a real grant application. Minor weaknesses include a placeholder contact line and slightly dense opening paragraph.
strengths: Excellent use of bold formatting on key metrics ($1,500,000, 1,200 families, 85%, 70%, $2,200, 10 days) that makes critical data immediately scannable
Strong formal tone with precise, institutional language appropriate for a major foundation like Hilton—avoids jargon while maintaining professionalism
Compelling need statement with specific, local data (28,458 people, $2,781 vs $1,233) that creates urgency without melodrama
Clear delivery model description that explains 'diversion' in plain language ('stops shelter stays before they start')
Robust evidence section citing both external models (King County) and internal pilot data (410 families, 83% stability)
Excellent equity section that goes beyond demographics to address specific access barriers (undocumented caregivers, transit, childcare)
Proper acronym definitions on first use (LAHSA, DPSS, HMIS, McKinney-Vento)
Strong funder alignment that uses their exact language ('upstream prevention,' 'family homelessness') naturally
Comprehensive budget context showing significant leverage ($4.75M confirmed match)
Realistic, measurable outcomes with specific targets and timeframes
weaknesses: Contact section uses placeholder text '[Contact Name, Title | Email | Phone]' instead of actual details provided (Jasmine Lee, CEO, jlee@mfhp.org, (213) 555-0890)
Need paragraph is slightly dense at 4 sentences when template recommends 1-2; could be tightened
Missing the signer information (Marcus D. Nguyen) that was provided in the scenario—though this may be intentional if funder doesn't require it
The opening header block adds formatting that may not paste cleanly into all Word templates, though it does enhance visual hierarchy

outputs.content:
Need
In Los Angeles County, 28,458 people in families experienced homelessness in the past year; 69% of family heads are women, and an average two-bedroom rent is $2,781 while the median CalWORKs (California Work Opportunity and Responsibility to Kids) grant for a family of three is $1,233. A shelter entry disrupts work and school, deepens trauma, and delays return to permanent housing—impacts concentrated among Black and Latino single-mother households in Service Planning Areas (SPAs) 2, 4, and 6.

Solution
The Family Diversion & Stability Initiative prevents a shelter stay before it starts by helping 1,200 families resolve immediate housing crises across Los Angeles County. Trained specialists conduct diversion screening at the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) Coordinated Entry System, mediate with landlords or family, provide flexible cash assistance, and offer 1:1 housing stabilization coaching. Key partners include the Department of Public Social Services (DPSS) CalWORKs offices, Neighborhood Legal Services, 211 LA, and school district McKinney-Vento liaisons.

Request
Metro Family Housing Partnership requests **$1,500,000** from the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation for family homelessness diversion and rapid resolution from July 2025–June 2027. The total program budget is $6,500,000, leveraging $3,000,000 in Measure H funding, $1,250,000 from private donors/corporate partners, and $500,000 in-kind; estimated cost is $5,417 per family.

Outcomes
We will **divert 1,200 families** from shelter, with **85% stably housed at 6 months** and 70% sustaining housing at 12 months. We will keep average assistance per family under $2,200 and **reduce average time to resolution to 10 days**. We will disaggregate results by SPA and race/ethnicity.

Evidence & Evaluation
Diversion models in King County and Los Angeles County show 70–80% housing retention with flexible assistance; our 2023 pilot diverted 410 families with 83% six‑month stability. We will track outcomes via the Homeless Management Information System (HMIS), case records, landlord verification, and 6- and 12‑month surveys, with quarterly dashboard reviews.

Organizational Capacity
Founded in 1988, we served 18,000 people last year across prevention, shelter, and housing with 220 staff and a countywide footprint. A licensed clinical social worker leads our Housing Stabilization team, supported by multilingual navigators and an HMIS data unit; audits have been unmodified for 10 years with six months of operating reserves.

Funder Fit
This Initiative advances family homelessness prevention through upstream prevention, aligning with Hilton’s focus on solutions that keep families housed.

Equity & Community Voice
We target SPAs with the highest rates of Black family homelessness and deliver culturally responsive services; flexible aid also removes barriers for undocumented caregivers. A parent advisory council and McKinney‑Vento liaisons shaped program design; services include evening hours, English/Spanish support, childcare, and transit/Lyft assistance.

Timeline
Months 1–3: hire and train 12 diversion specialists; Months 4–24: operate countywide; Month 12: midpoint evaluation; Month 24: final report and knowledge‑sharing brief.

Sustainability
Post‑grant funding will come from Measure H renewal, Medi‑Cal Community Supports partnerships, and committed private co‑investors.

Contact
For questions: [CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]. Signer (if required): [SIGNER NAME, TITLE].

evaluation.reasoning: The output demonstrates strong formal tone and clear structure with effective use of data and metrics. However, it has critical completion errors (placeholder text in Contact section), exceeds the 400-word maximum at approximately 450 words, and includes minor formatting inconsistencies that would require editing before submission.
strengths: Excellent formal tone appropriate for institutional funder—precise, data-driven, avoids superlatives and jargon
Strong use of bolding for key metrics ($1,500,000, 1,200 families, 85% housed, 10 days) that aids skimmability
Concrete, specific data throughout (28,458 people, $2,781 rent vs $1,233 CalWORKs, 83% pilot success rate)
Effective acronym management—defines LAHSA, DPSS, HMIS, CalWORKs on first use
Clear alignment with funder priorities using their language ('family homelessness prevention,' 'upstream prevention')
Strong equity section that names specific populations and barriers (Black families, undocumented caregivers, SPAs)
Logical flow from need through solution to outcomes matches best practices for executive summaries
weaknesses: Contact section contains unformatted placeholder text '[CONTACT NAME, TITLE, EMAIL, PHONE]' instead of actual details provided (Jasmine Lee, CEO, etc.)—this is a critical error that makes the document unusable without manual correction
Exceeds stated 250-400 word limit at approximately 450 words; would need trimming for compliance
Minor inconsistency: 'Signer (if required)' appears with placeholder when the prompt indicates signer should only be included if funder requires it—should either populate or omit entirely
Funder Fit section is somewhat redundant ('prevention through upstream prevention') and could be tightened
Missing the explicit 'invitation' language in Contact section that the prompt requested ('Brief invitation + contact details')
